I had an 8cm long pet mantis. One day when I was trying to gently prod him towards some water, he whipped around and grabbed my finger. I'm quite proud of the fact I didn't jerk away as that could really have hurt him, but I still had to figure out how to get him off without hurting him. When he realised he had actually caught something, he leaned in to start munching. I felt his little mandibles nibbling at my skin and thought to myself "If I give him 5-10 minutes he MIGHT break my skin, so I should think of a solution quickly." Thankfully, he'd grabbed the tip of my finger, meaning half his arm was only pressing against my finger nail and unable to pierce it with his rose-thorn-like spines. I was able to twist my finger in just the right way to make him lose his grip. He let go, looked vaguely confused, but mainly unbothered by the experience. ^^ I closed the terrarium and went to wash my finger thoroughly where his spines had poked skin. Nothing adverse happened to me either. ^^

Sometimes I think I'd like a pet mantis that was a foot long, because it would be easier to interact with it, but then I remember how dumb they are and how much more capable it would be of munching me and settle for the 2-10cm ones. x)

I can vouch for the potency of Solenopsis invicta venom. I was hiking in the woods of Choctaw County, Alabama, one summer morning, back in the late 1980s. Being a bit parched on that sunny, steamy day, I stopped for a cool drink of water from my canteen, and after a few moments, noticed an irritating prickling and burning around my lower legs. As I'm a bit sensitive to brushing against certain kinds of grasses native to the area, I dismissed it as that. As the sensation kept creeping higher, though, I also noticed the feeling of things crawling on me. In that moment, I looked down and discovered that I'd chosen to stop with my feet right in the middle of a fire-ant mound that had been somewhat hidden by weeds growing around it, and now had hundreds of the vicious buggers all over my legs and inside my shoes, stinging assiduously. I later did an estimate and came up with a rough tally of around 200 stings across both legs.

After retreating to a safe distance, I brushed off the ants on my legs, and removed most of the ones in my socks and shoes. I soon began to feel a bit shaky, and decided to return home, which was only 10 minutes' walk away. By the time I got there, I was shaking all over and feeling curious chills and weakness -- could hardly hold a cup of coffee steady enough to take a sip.

Fortunately, that's as bad as it got, but it was a stark reminder that even tiny poisonous beasts can cause real trouble in sufficient numbers.

In his memoir of fighting in the Pacific in WWII, titled "Helmet for my Pillow," Robert Leckie tells a story of a "land crab" which would crawl out of a nearby ditch and cut the rope holding up a specific soldier's hammock. The crab was so big that they could hear it crawling through the loam, and every time it cut the rope, it scuttled back into the ditch and the soldier would tie his hammock back up the same place, swearing loudly. This happened over and over, nearly all night.

Besides being a military history buff, I also love nature documentaries, but I never saw or read about a land crab large enough to fit this description. It wasn't until that one picture of a coconut crab on a trash can started circulating that I finally got to see one.

Just wondering, how common is soccer in the US?

I mean I'm not a footie fan but the game is damn catchy, exciting (because of the low scores where games can turn on a dime), and it's so easy to play (because all you need are four objects for the goals and a tin can for the ball). Obviously it got popular in the UK after the migrations to America (Hense it not being a big thing in the US), I imagine it would catch on.
American football is a fantastic expansion on the game of 'rugby', traditionally known as rugby football (the type of football played in the town of Rugby, back when lots of ball games were called 'football'), but me and my friends used to avoid rugby because it requires a particular set of goal posts with a crossbar, and a grassy floor that you can tackle people into without them eating carpark.

I just wondered how popular the game of association football, or soccer (named after 'association football, because the game only appears in the US after it got big enough to have associations holding tournaments) was in the US because I feel that, like the game of chess, it's just simple and fun. I raised mantis nymphs when I was a kid, for our garden and fruit trees (natural damaging insect control). Occasionally I kept one as a pet, like one very large female who lived longer than average life span for one, probably because she was a pet and had it really good. Anyway, I also kept fish and let her eat guppies when she showed interest. I took her on vacation with me and staying somewhere in the southern US once we had a cockroach in our hotel. My brothers caught it but couldn't kill it stepping on it and so I told them to put it in a wicker trash can and we set Jacqui on the edge. She caught it and it was much more of a struggle for her to eat than the guppies and small crickets she was used to. She started eating at the abdomen and you could tell the flailing legs was getting to her. After a moment she repositioned it so she could bite into the head and eat the brain and went back to the abdomen. After that, it stopped moving except for occasional limb twitches when she went back to the head. Totally had to think about this after seeing the Pickle Rick episode of Rick & Morty, I even wonder if whoever wrote that part of it had heard this story as I've told it online several times :D

One of the creepiest things about the bobbit worms is that they lack a brain. They're barely alive in the conventional sense; a machine-like predator, only a step above a carnivorous plant like the venus flytrap. Since they lack a central neural cluster, they are also very difficult to kill, and even if you cut them into pieces, each piece can grow into a fully viable bobbit worm.

There is no way to know exactly how many stings I got, since my parents didn't take me to a doctor, but it was a bunch, I can tell you that. I thought I was going to die - literally.
